Dear Mrs. Valdes:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
March 5, 2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract
and Modified Implementation Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a
written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing
rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved; this includes identifying
behaviorally specific action steps.
o Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Individuals directly responsible for implementing the corrective action step for
each licensing statute and rule, Contract item, DHHS policy or MISEP section
citation, e.g. workers, supervisors, program managers, director, etc.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
implemented and completed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved; this
includes identifying specific action steps for continuous monitoring.
o MiSACWIS users with access to the Book of Business, InfoView Reports
and the Monthly Child Welfare Management Report should incorporate the
use of these tools as well as other data management reports released by
the Department for continuous monitoring.
 Signature of the responsible party and date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
322 E. Stockbridge Ave
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
(269) 251-2471

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make
a licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
One of eight active foster care home files reviewed did not have documentation that
the reevaluation was completed and sent to DCWL within 15-days of the license
expiring. The license of this home expired on 11/18/20 and the report was signed by
the supervisor on 11/17/20.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information:
(c) A summary of information pertinent to the updated
services plan received since the last service plan from the
child, the child's parents or legal guardian, foster parents,
referring agency, and others, unless the agency documents
why any of these entities cannot be involved.
Two of eight open foster care case files reviewed did not have each Updated
Service Plan completed as required. This involved one USP in each case file that
had documentation of a replacement but the placement section of the USP was
incomplete in describing the reasons for the replacement.
THIS IS A REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2020 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH
AN APPROVED CAP ON 5/19/20.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
MISEP 6.16 Supervisory Oversight (commitment 66)
The supervisor shall meet at least monthly with the
caseworker and discuss each case’s status. The supervisor
4

will approve each service plan only after a face to face
meeting.
One of three active Independent Living Case files reviewed did not have
documentation that the supervisor met with the case manager each month. This
involved missing documentation of one month for this period under review.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings.
722-06B - page
2-6
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home
cases:
• Case service plan development,
• permanency goal changes,
• placement preservation/disruption
• permanency planning at six months in care annual
transition planning for youth every six months from age 16
until case closure
• 90 day discharge planning for youth
• Case closure
Requested by family
5

Two of three active Independent Living Case files reviewed did not have
documentation that the agency met all of the requirements for the FTM in each of
the two case files. This involved two documented FTMs that occurred outside of the
30-day prior time frame for an Updated Service Plan.
Five of eight active foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the agency met all of the requirements for the FTM in each of the five case files. This
involved five missing FTMs for replacement of the youth, two missing FTMs for USP,
and one late FTM for a USP.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2020 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 5/19/2020, THE 2019 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 4/15/2019, THE 2018 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 6/20/2018 AND THE 2017 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 4/12/2017.
DHHS Policy DHHS-69 Required for placement change.
FOM 722-03
Page 18
When it is necessary to move a child, the original
placement selection criteria and standards apply. First
consideration must be given to returning the child to the
parent or placing the child with siblings or with a suitable
relative. If a child’s needs have changed, written re-
evaluation of the placement selection criteria is required on
the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary,
and summarized in the case service plan.
One of three active Independent Living case files reviewed did not have the required
DHHS-69 documented as being completed on four placement changes in the case
file.
Three of eight active Foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation
that the required DHHS-69 was completed for each replacement of the youth. This
involved four missing DHHS-69s on four replacements, two DHHS-69s completed
late, and one missing the effective date.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2020 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 5/19/2020, THE 2019 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 4/15/2019 AND THE 2018 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 6/20/2018.
DHHS Policy - Required Participation in Development - Parents and Youth
FOM 722-08C - over 14-Years Old & Foster Parent / Caregiver
Page 2
Upon completion of the parent-agency treatment plan and
service agreement, the parent is given a copy for review. Foster
6

care workers need to ensure the parent understands all areas
within the agreement. Parents and youths age 14 and older
must sign the PATP. If a parent or youth is unavailable or
refuses to sign the PATP, foster care workers must identify, and
document additional action needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and compliance
with the PATP. As the goals are achieved, modified or
expanded, the updated PATP will reflect this process. Parents
and youths age 14 and older must participate in the
development of each updated treatment plan, allowing for
opportunity to evaluate their progress towards completing goals.
The individual activities required by the foster parent/caregiver
to meet the specific individual needs of the child placed in their
home are included in the PATP. The foster parent/caregiver
must be included in the PATP process. The foster
parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates that the
foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
Additionally, the PATP details the services and activities
provided by the foster care worker to assist the foster
parent/caregiver in caring for the child.
CI 17-096 Treatment Plan Signature Timeframes and
Documentation Requirements
When the treatment plan is completed, signatures for all
appropriate case members must be obtained. Signatures from
all appropriate case members, including youth ages 14 and
older for foster care and youth ages 11 and older for juvenile
justice, should be obtained before the corresponding court
hearing. All treatment plans with a report date of August 1,
2017, or later must have signatures from all appropriate case
members within 30 days of the report date.
Two of three active Independent Living case files reviewed did not have
documentation that all of the requirements for participating in the development of the
service plan were met. This involved one service plan in each case file with the
youth’s signature beyond the 30-day time frame.
Six of eight active foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that all
of the requirements for participating in the development of the service plan were
met. This involved four late (beyond 30-days) parent signatures, three late (beyond
30-days) caregiver signatures, eight missing parent signatures, five missing
caregiver signatures, and one missing youth signature.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2020 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 5/19/2020, THE 2019 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 4/15/2019, THE 2018 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
7

APPROVED CAP ON 6/20/2018 AND THE 2017 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 4/12/2017.
DHHS Policy CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH CHILD RETURNED HOME
FOM 722-
6H(Page 6)
First Month After Return Home
The caseworker must have weekly face-to-face contacts
with the parent(s) and the child, in the home. At least one
contact each calendar month must include a private
meeting between the child and the caseworker. This period
of contacts may be extended to 90 days, if necessary.
Subsequent Months
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face
contacts with the parent(s) and the child, each calendar
month, in the home, until case closure, unless the family is
receiving Family Reunification or Families First services.
One of eight active foster care case files reviewed involving a child’s return to the
parental home (one of two), did not have documentation that the agency met the
visitation in the home requirements. This involved one missing visit for the month of
February 2021 in the parental home.
DHHS Policy Medical Passports
FOM 801 – page
11-13
Updated Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
One of eight active Foster care case files reviewed did not have the required
documentation for the Medical Passports in the case file. This involved no
documentation of a Medical Passport being provided to the caregivers for two
replacements in the one case file.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM THE 2020 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 5/19/2020, THE 2019 RENEWAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 4/15/2019 AND THE 2018 ANNUAL INSPECTION WITH AN
APPROVED CAP ON 6/20/2018.
DHHS Policy - Supervisory Approval USP
FOM 722-09 -
Page 27 -
Prior to finalizing, the USP along with the required
assessments (FANS, CANS, etc.) must be reviewed and
8

approved by the foster care supervisor only after a face-to-
face meeting with the foster care worker.
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of
the report date.
One of eight active Foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
each service plan was approved by the supervisor within 14-days of the report date.
This involved one service plan not approved within the 14-day time frame.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 During this inspection, it was discovered that the coding of social work
contacts was not consistent and often items were coded in different ways
within the same case file. This was discussed at the exit meeting and the
agency agreed that they will examine this in detail and develop a system of
quality assurance to ensure that compliance is being met.
 During the review of the special evaluations completed by the agency, it was
discovered that the primary process of the corrective action plan was present,
but their development of monitoring compliance was scheduled to only occur
during an annual inspection. We discussed the importance of ongoing
monitoring that would occur more often. The agency agreed with the need to
make this change to ensure that compliance is being met.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request any consultation at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. This corrective action plan was regarding
the 2020 Annual Licensing inspection.
Phone interviews were conducted with various staff, ranging from case managers to
administration. Each individual interviewed reported a belief that they were
9

supported by their manager/supervisor. Each also reported having the appropriate
items to continue with the required services during the COVID-19 restrictions. The
direct workers did report some difficulty in the beginning of the restrictions, but they
also reported that they have been able to develop systems to overcome the first
difficulties.
VII. ANALYST REPORT DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
No safety concerns were noted. The field Analyst interviewed four licensed foster
homes and three relative placement homes. This involved interviews with seven
caregivers and two children.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
